analysis.raw_analysis:
1) TRANSFORMATION: Input and output are same size (10x10), ratio 1:1.

2) PATTERN: Each connected orange region (color 5) is repainted to the color of the single nonzero pixel in row0 whose column falls inside that region's horizontal span; all other pixels remain unchanged.

3) KEY CHANGES:
Ex1 (type: vertical-align recolor; visual: 3 top singles above 3 regions): 5->1 (left), 5->7 (right), 5->4 (bottom).
Ex2: 5->6 (top-center), 5->2 (left vertical), 5->8 (bottom-right).
Ex3: 5->1 (left), 5->6 (middle), 5->7 (right).

=== INPUT-INPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Same: three single nonzero pixels in row0 (colors vary) and several connected regions of color 5 at various positions; other pixels unchanged.
- Different: colors and columns of the three row0 pixels vary; shapes/positions of the distinct color-5 objects vary.

=== OUTPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Exactly same: all non-5 pixels unchanged (row0 singles remain same colors/cols). Every output has each original 5-region uniformly repainted.

=== INPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Rule: For each connected region of color 5, repaint all its cells to the color of the single nonzero pixel in row0 whose column lies within that region's horizontal span. (uses row0 colors: e.g. 1,4,7 or 2,6,8)

Reference objects: The three single nonzero pixels in the top row remain unchanged and serve as color references aligned to columns.

Grid pattern: For every connected orange region (color 5), find which top-row single’s column falls inside that region’s horizontal span; repaint the entire region to that top pixel’s color. All other pixels unchanged.

Objects: Recurring/critical objects = connected color-5 blocks; mapping is horizontal-span → top reference color.

=== GENERAL RULE ===
1. Step 1: IF a pixel is in row 0 and its color is not 0 THEN record its column index j and its color value c as a top-row reference (map column j -> color c).

2. Step 2: IF a set of orthogonally connected cells all have color 5 THEN treat that set as a distinct region R and compute R's horizontal span [min_col, max_col] as the smallest and largest column indices of cells in R.

3. Step 3: IF a distinct region R has exactly one recorded top-row reference whose column j satisfies min_col <= j <= max_col THEN change the color of every cell in R to the color value c of that referenced top-row pixel.

4. Step 4: IF a distinct region R has more than one recorded top-row reference whose column lies within min_col <= j <= max_col THEN choose the reference with the smallest column j (leftmost) and change the color of every cell in R to that chosen reference's color value.

5. Step 5: IF a distinct region R has no recorded top-row reference with column in min_col <= j <= max_col THEN leave every cell of R unchanged.

6. Step 6: IF a pixel is not part of any distinct color-5 region THEN leave its color unchanged.

2. Step 2: IF a set of orthogonally connected cells all have color 5 THEN treat that set as a distinct region R and compute R's horizontal span [min_col, max_col] as the smallest and largest column indices of cells in R.

3. Step 3: IF a distinct region R has exactly one recorded top-row reference whose column j satisfies min_col <= j <= max_col THEN change the color of every cell in R to the color value c of that referenced top-row pixel.

4. Step 4: IF a distinct region R has more than one recorded top-row reference whose column lies within min_col <= j <= max_col THEN choose the reference with the smallest column j (leftmost) and change the color of every cell in R to that chosen reference's color value.

5. Step 5: IF a distinct region R has no recorded top-row reference with column in min_col <= j <= max_col THEN leave every cell of R unchanged.

6. Step 6: IF a pixel is not part of any distinct color-5 region THEN leave its color unchanged.

general_steps.instruction: Step 1: Under NO circumstances change objects matching the condition in this step; treat them as immutable reference objects and do not modify their color, size, position or shape.
general_steps.condition: Any single-cell object located in row 0 (top row) whose color value is not 0 (i.e., a one-cell nonzero pixel at coordinates (0, j)).

general_steps.instruction: Step 2: For each pixel in row 0 whose color is not 0, record a top-row reference mapping from its column index to its color value (create a set of column->color reference entries).
general_steps.condition: Any pixel at row index 0 with color != 0 (top-row nonzero single pixels).

general_steps.instruction: Step 3: Identify each distinct region R formed by orthogonally connected cells all of color 5 and compute R's horizontal span [min_col, max_col] as the smallest and largest column indices of cells in R.
general_steps.condition: Any connected region (connected orthogonally, 4-neighborhood) composed only of color 5 (all cells in the region have color value 5).

general_steps.instruction: Step 4: For each distinct region R (as defined above), if there is exactly one recorded top-row reference whose column j satisfies min_col <= j <= max_col, recolor every cell of R to that top-row reference's color; leave all other pixels unchanged.
general_steps.condition: A distinct orthogonally connected region composed only of color 5 whose computed horizontal span [min_col, max_col] contains exactly one recorded top-row reference column j (i.e., there exists exactly one mapping column j->color c with min_col <= j <= max_col).

steps.instruction: CROP: Object 1 (Single isolated pixel of color 1 in the top row (a 1x1 dot).)
steps.substep_reasoning: Cropping to object 1 to apply transform transformation. Bbox: [0, 1, 0, 1]

steps.instruction: TRANSFORM: Object 1 (transform)
steps.substep_reasoning: Applying transform to object 1 based on condition: Any single-cell object located in row 0 (top row) whose color value is not 0 (i.e., a one-cell nonzero pixel at coordinates (0, j)).

steps.instruction: UNCROP: Object 1 back to full grid
